About the Character: Whoopi Goldberg portrayed Guinan, the enigmatic El-Aurian bartender of the USS Enterprise-D in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Guinan is a long-lived and wise character who often provides guidance and advice to Captain Picard and the crew. Her unique ability to sense disruptions in the space-time continuum and her deep understanding of the human condition made her an invaluable asset on the ship. Guinan's mysterious past and her complex relationship with Picard are key elements of her character, though much of her history remains unexplored in the series. Goldberg's portrayal of Guinan was notable for its depth and serenity, making the character one of the most beloved recurring figures in the Star Trek universe.
About the Guest:
Whoopi Goldberg is an acclaimed actress, comedian, and television personality who has achieved EGOT status, having won an Emmy, Grammy, Oscar, and Tony Award. Her breakout role came in The Color Purple (1985), for which she earned an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress. She won the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress for her role as the psychic Oda Mae Brown in Ghost (1990), a performance that solidified her status as one of Hollywood's top stars. Beyond film, Goldberg is known for her stand-up comedy and was one of the first African-American women to gain prominence in that field.

Goldberg is also a well-known television personality, having co-hosted The View since 2007, where her outspoken opinions on social and political issues have made her a major voice in daytime television. Beyond entertainment, Goldberg has used her platform to advocate for various social causes, including LGBTQ rights and AIDS awareness. Her versatility as a performer, spanning dramatic roles, comedy, and talk show hosting, has made her one of the most iconic and influential figures in entertainment.

About the Character: John Larroquette appeared as Maltz, a Klingon officer serving under Commander Kruge in Star Trek III: The Search for Spock. Maltz is one of Kruge's loyal subordinates who assists in capturing the USS Enterprise and participates in the mission to recover the Genesis Device. After Kruge's death in battle with Captain Kirk, Maltz is taken prisoner by Kirk. His role is relatively small, but Larroquette’s portrayal of the Klingon officer adds depth to the film’s depiction of the Klingon crew.
About the Guest:
John Larroquette is a renowned American actor known primarily for his comedic work in television. He gained widespread recognition for his role as the wisecracking attorney Dan Fielding on the sitcom Night Court (1984-1992), for which he won four consecutive Emmy Awards for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series. His ability to mix humor with a darker, more cynical edge made Dan Fielding one of the most memorable TV characters of the 1980s. Larroquette also had notable roles in shows like The John Larroquette Show and Boston Legal.

In addition to his work in television, Larroquette has had a successful career in film and on stage. He appeared in movies such as Stripes (1981) and Richie Rich (1994) and has had guest appearances on numerous television shows. He won a Tony Award for Best Featured Actor in a Musical for his performance in the 2011 revival of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. Larroquette’s distinctive voice and presence have made him a versatile actor capable of both comedic and dramatic roles.

About the Character: Kim Darby played Miri in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Miri." Miri is one of the children living on a planet where a biological experiment has gone wrong, leaving the adults dead and the children in a state of arrested aging. As Miri begins to transition into adulthood, she faces the onset of a deadly disease that affects all adults. She forms a bond with Captain Kirk, showing signs of affection for him as she tries to help the crew find a cure. Darby’s performance captures the vulnerability and confusion of a young girl caught between childhood and adulthood, making the episode one of the more emotionally charged installments of the series.
About the Guest:
Kim Darby is an American actress best known for her role as Mattie Ross in the 1969 film True Grit, where she starred alongside John Wayne. Her portrayal of the determined young woman seeking justice for her father’s murder became iconic, and the film itself remains a classic of the Western genre. Darby’s performance earned her widespread acclaim and launched her career as a leading actress in Hollywood.

Though True Grit remains her most recognized role, Darby continued to work in both television and film throughout the 1970s and 1980s. She appeared in several TV shows, including Gunsmoke, The Fugitive, and The Streets of San Francisco, and had roles in films such as The Strawberry Statement and Better Off Dead. Despite never achieving the same level of fame as with True Grit, Darby maintained a steady career and is remembered for her compelling performances in a variety of genres.

About the Character: In a memorable cameo, Stephen Hawking appeared as himself in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "Descent, Part I." He plays a holographic version of himself in a scene where Lieutenant Commander Data engages in a game of poker with Hawking, Sir Isaac Newton, and Albert Einstein on the holodeck. The scene humorously highlights Hawking’s brilliance and wit as he plays alongside historical geniuses. Hawking was the only real-life person to ever appear as himself in the Star Trek universe, and his cameo is remembered as a delightful intersection of real-world science and science fiction.
About the Guest:
Stephen Hawking was a world-renowned theoretical physicist, cosmologist, and author whose groundbreaking work on black holes and the nature of the universe earned him international fame. Hawking’s most famous work, A Brief History of Time (1988), became a bestseller and introduced complex concepts of astrophysics to a general audience. Despite living with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which left him almost completely paralyzed, Hawking continued his academic work and public engagements for decades, communicating through a speech-generating device. His contributions to the study of quantum mechanics and general relativity remain some of the most influential in modern science.

In addition to his scientific achievements, Hawking became a pop culture icon, making appearances on television shows such as The Simpsons and The Big Bang Theory. His cameo in Star Trek: The Next Generation was particularly memorable, as he played himself in a poker game with holographic versions of Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein. Hawking’s ability to blend his intellectual pursuits with a sense of humor and his remarkable personal resilience made him one of the most admired figures in both the scientific community and popular culture.

About the Character: Joan Collins portrayed Edith Keeler in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "The City on the Edge of Forever." Edith is a social worker and pacifist in 1930s New York, running a mission for the homeless. Captain Kirk and Spock, who have traveled back in time, discover that Edith's survival or death plays a pivotal role in history. While Kirk falls in love with her, Spock determines that she must die to prevent a disastrous future where the Nazis win World War II. Collins’ portrayal of Edith as an idealistic and compassionate figure brings a poignant emotional depth to the episode, which is widely regarded as one of the best in the Star Trek franchise.
About the Guest:
Joan Collins is a British actress and author, best known for her role as Alexis Carrington on the primetime soap opera Dynasty (1981-1989). Her portrayal of the scheming, glamorous ex-wife of Blake Carrington became one of the most iconic television characters of the 1980s, earning her widespread fame and several Golden Globe nominations, including a win in 1983. Collins' performance as Alexis helped turn Dynasty into a cultural phenomenon and cemented her status as a symbol of opulent, dramatic television.

Before her role on Dynasty, Collins had a successful film career, appearing in movies such as The Girl in the Red Velvet Swing (1955) and The Stud (1978), as well as a variety of British films. Beyond acting, Collins has written several memoirs and novels, many of which have become bestsellers. Her career longevity and her larger-than-life persona, both on and off-screen, have made her a fixture in Hollywood and British entertainment for more than six decades.

About the Character: Kelsey Grammer played Captain Morgan Bateson in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "Cause and Effect." Bateson is the captain of the USS Bozeman, a starship that becomes trapped in a temporal causality loop for over 80 years without realizing it. His ship repeatedly collides with the Enterprise-D, causing a loop in time. Grammer’s portrayal of Bateson is brief but impactful, as he conveys the shock and confusion of a man suddenly finding himself in a future he doesn’t understand. The episode is a fan favorite due to its complex time-loop narrative and Grammer's commanding performance.
About the Guest:
Kelsey Grammer is an American actor, producer, and director, best known for his role as Dr. Frasier Crane, a character he portrayed for 20 years on two of the most popular sitcoms in television history, Cheers (1984-1993) and Frasier (1993-2004). Grammer’s performance as the erudite but often hapless psychiatrist earned him four Primetime Emmy Awards and widespread acclaim as one of television’s greatest comedic actors. His portrayal of Frasier became so beloved that the character remains a pop culture icon, symbolizing both intellectual wit and comedic vulnerability.

In addition to his success on television, Grammer has had a prolific career as a voice actor, appearing in animated shows like The Simpsons (as Sideshow Bob) and films such as Toy Story 2 and Anastasia. He has also taken on more dramatic roles in series like Boss and The Last Tycoon. Outside of acting, Grammer has worked as a producer and director, including for Frasier, and is the co-founder of the production company Grammnet Productions. His contributions to television have made him one of the most respected figures in the industry.

About the Character: Tom Morello, the guitarist from Rage Against the Machine, appeared as Crewman Mitchell in Star Trek: Voyager episode "Good Shepherd." Morello’s character is a crewman aboard the USS Voyager who is seen briefly during an interaction with Captain Janeway. His role is minor, but the appearance of Morello, a known Star Trek fan, delighted fans of both the show and his music. Morello's cameo, while brief, showcases his personal love for the franchise.
About the Guest:
Tom Morello is an American musician, songwriter, and political activist, best known as the lead guitarist for the rock band Rage Against the Machine. Known for his innovative and unconventional guitar techniques, Morello’s playing style combines heavy riffs with effects-laden sounds that mimic everything from turntables to sirens. His work with Rage Against the Machine helped the band achieve critical and commercial success with politically charged songs like "Killing in the Name" and "Bulls on Parade." Morello’s guitar work has been recognized as groundbreaking, earning him a spot on several "greatest guitarist" lists, including Rolling Stone’s.

In addition to his work with Rage Against the Machine, Morello has played with several other groups, including Audioslave, Prophets of Rage, and his solo project, The Nightwatchman. He is also a committed activist, using his platform to speak out on issues such as workers' rights, social justice, and anti-corporate movements. Morello’s combination of musical talent and political engagement has made him one of the most influential figures in modern rock music.

About the Character: Director Bryan Singer made a brief cameo as an unnamed crewman aboard the Enterprise-E in Star Trek: Nemesis. His appearance is quick, occurring during a scene where he is seen on the bridge of the ship. Singer, a fan of Star Trek, took the opportunity to be part of the franchise in this small, uncredited role. While his time on screen is fleeting, it marked a fun moment for fans who recognized the famous filmmaker.
About the Guest:
Bryan Singer is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work in the X-Men film series and the crime thriller The Usual Suspects (1995). The Usual Suspects, which earned Singer an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay, propelled him to fame with its complex narrative and iconic plot twist. His success continued with his work on the X-Men franchise, where he directed four of the films, starting with X-Men (2000) and X2 (2003). His work on the X-Men films is credited with helping to shape the modern superhero genre, bringing more depth and character development to a genre previously known for action and spectacle.

In addition to his contributions to the superhero genre, Singer directed other high-profile projects, including Superman Returns (2006) and Bohemian Rhapsody (2018), the latter of which earned an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture. However, Singer’s career has been marred by numerous allegations of misconduct, which have cast a shadow over his accomplishments in Hollywood. Despite the controversies, his impact on the film industry, particularly in the superhero genre, remains significant.

About the Character: Seth MacFarlane appeared as Ensign Rivers in two episodes of Star Trek: Enterprise, "The Forgotten" and "Affliction." Ensign Rivers is a minor character who serves aboard the Enterprise NX-01. MacFarlane, a lifelong Star Trek fan, relished the chance to appear in the franchise. His role as Rivers is straightforward, serving as a bridge officer during some of the ship's missions. Although the role is small, MacFarlane's appearance in Star Trek was a fun crossover for fans of both his work in animation and the Star Trek universe.
About the Guest:
Seth MacFarlane is an American actor, writer, producer, and comedian, best known as the creator of the animated television series Family Guy, American Dad!, and The Cleveland Show. MacFarlane’s unique blend of sharp wit, satire, and often controversial humor has made him one of the most successful figures in television animation. Family Guy has become a cultural staple since its debut in 1999, despite initially being canceled and later revived due to fan demand. MacFarlane voices several of the show's main characters, including Peter Griffin, Brian the dog, and Stewie Griffin, showcasing his versatility as a performer.

In addition to his success in animation, MacFarlane has ventured into live-action television and film. He created and starred in the sci-fi comedy series The Orville, which pays homage to shows like Star Trek while blending humor with thoughtful storytelling. MacFarlane also directed and starred in the comedy films Ted (2012) and A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014). Beyond his work in television and film, MacFarlane is a talented singer and has released several albums of big band and swing music, further showcasing his wide-ranging creative talents.

About the Character: Iggy Pop played Yelgrun, a Vorta operative of the Dominion, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episode “The Magnificent Ferengi.” Yelgrun is sent to facilitate a prisoner exchange involving the Ferengi and their Starfleet ally. His sarcastic and dismissive attitude toward the Ferengi provides a humorous contrast to the more menacing Vorta characters seen in the series. Iggy Pop’s portrayal of Yelgrun is memorable for his deadpan delivery and distinctive voice, adding a quirky dynamic to an episode focused on comedic misadventures.
About the Guest:
ggy Pop, often referred to as the "Godfather of Punk," is an American singer, songwriter, and actor best known as the frontman of the influential punk rock band The Stooges. Known for his wild onstage antics, including stage diving and performing shirtless, Iggy Pop’s raw, primal energy and confrontational style helped shape the punk music scene in the late 1960s and 1970s. The Stooges, with songs like "I Wanna Be Your Dog" and "Search and Destroy," became seminal figures in the genre, influencing countless artists in punk, rock, and alternative music.

Beyond his work with The Stooges, Iggy Pop has had a successful solo career, with hits like "Lust for Life" and "The Passenger." He is also known for his collaborations with artists like David Bowie, who produced several of his albums. In addition to his music career, Iggy Pop has appeared in several films, including Cry-Baby and Dead Man, and has become an enduring figure in popular culture. His fearless approach to both music and life has earned him a reputation as a true rock icon.

About the Character: Christian Slater made a brief cameo as a communications officer in Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country. In the film, Slater's character awakens Captain Sulu of the USS Excelsior to deliver an important message regarding the status of the Enterprise. Although his screen time is minimal, Slater’s appearance was a nod to his real-life connection to Star Trek, as his mother, Mary Jo Slater, worked as the casting director for the film. His cameo delighted fans who recognized him in the blink-and-you-miss-it role.
About the Guest:
Christian Slater is an American actor who rose to fame in the late 1980s and early 1990s with his roles in films like Heathers (1988), Pump Up the Volume (1990), and True Romance (1993). Known for his rebellious, edgy characters, Slater became a teen heartthrob and a symbol of the angst-ridden Generation X. His portrayal of the charismatic yet troubled J.D. in Heathers cemented his status as a cult icon, as the dark high school comedy became a beloved classic over the years.

Throughout the 1990s and 2000s, Slater continued to work in both film and television, appearing in projects such as Broken Arrow (1996), Hard Rain (1998), and Mr. Robot (2015-2019). His performance in Mr. Robot as the titular character earned him widespread acclaim, including a Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor in a Television Series. Slater's ability to reinvent himself over the decades, transitioning from teen idol to respected character actor, has made him a lasting presence in Hollywood.

About the Character: Christopher Plummer played the iconic role of General Chang, a Klingon military commander, in Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country. Chang is a ruthless but cultured warrior who quotes Shakespeare throughout the film, underscoring his love of Earth literature. As one of the main antagonists, Chang leads a conspiracy to assassinate Chancellor Gorkon and prevent peace between the Klingon Empire and the Federation. Plummer’s portrayal of Chang is one of the most memorable villains in the Star Trek films, with his theatrical flair and sophisticated demeanor making him a formidable adversary to Captain Kirk.
About the Guest:
Christopher Plummer was a legendary Canadian actor whose career spanned over seven decades, during which he became one of the most respected actors in both film and theater. Plummer is best known for his role as Captain Georg von Trapp in The Sound of Music (1965), a performance that made him a household name. However, he often expressed mixed feelings about the film, preferring to focus on his extensive body of work in Shakespearean theater and dramatic roles. Plummer was celebrated for his commanding presence and his ability to bring depth to every character he portrayed, whether in classic plays or modern films.

Plummer's later career saw a resurgence, earning him widespread critical acclaim. He became the oldest actor to win an Academy Award when he took home the Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his role in Beginners (2010) at the age of 82. Other notable films include The Insider (1999), A Beautiful Mind (2001), and Knives Out (2019). Plummer's versatility as an actor, his dedication to the craft, and his longevity in the industry made him a revered figure in Hollywood and beyond.

About the Character: Mick Fleetwood, the drummer from Fleetwood Mac, made a cameo as an Antedean dignitary in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "Manhunt." His character is one of two alien ambassadors traveling to a peace conference aboard the Enterprise-D. The Antedeans are a fish-like species, and Fleetwood is completely unrecognizable under heavy prosthetic makeup. His role is silent, as the dignitaries remain in a catatonic state for much of the episode, with Fleetwood contributing more to the visual aspect of the character rather than any dialogue.
About the Guest:
Mick Fleetwood is a British musician and actor best known as the drummer and co-founder of the iconic rock band Fleetwood Mac. Formed in 1967, Fleetwood Mac went through several lineup changes before achieving global success with their 1977 album Rumours, one of the best-selling albums of all time. Fleetwood’s steady and creative drumming provided the backbone for the band’s sound, while his leadership helped guide the group through turbulent personal relationships and the pressures of fame. Along with Stevie Nicks, Lindsey Buckingham, and Christine and John McVie, Fleetwood helped craft some of the most enduring hits of the 1970s, including "Go Your Own Way," "Dreams," and "The Chain."

In addition to his music career, Fleetwood has dabbled in acting, making appearances in films and television. He famously played an Antedean dignitary in Star Trek: The Next Generation, where he was unrecognizable under heavy prosthetic makeup. Fleetwood has also written several memoirs, detailing the ups and downs of his career with Fleetwood Mac and his personal struggles with addiction. His legacy as a musician and his role in one of the greatest rock bands of all time have cemented his place in music history.

About the Character: Jason Alexander played Kurros, the leader of a group known as "The Think Tank," in Star Trek: Voyager episode "Think Tank." Kurros is an intellectual who offers Captain Janeway and the Voyager crew a solution to their problems in exchange for Seven of Nine joining his group. Alexander’s portrayal of Kurros is manipulative and self-assured, demonstrating his character’s belief in the superiority of intellect over all other qualities. This role was a departure from Alexander’s comedic persona, showcasing his ability to play a more sinister and calculating figure.
About the Guest:
Jason Alexander is best known for his portrayal of George Costanza on the long-running sitcom Seinfeld (1989-1998). As George, Alexander became synonymous with neurotic humor, delivering one of television’s most iconic comedic performances. His character’s constant schemes, anxieties, and frustrations, often driven by trivial concerns, made George Costanza one of the most relatable and enduring figures in TV comedy. Alexander’s portrayal earned him seven Primetime Emmy Award nominations and a place in television history, as Seinfeld remains one of the most popular and influential shows of all time.

Beyond Seinfeld, Alexander has had a diverse career in film, television, and stage. He has appeared in films like Pretty Woman (1990), Shallow Hal (2001), and Dunston Checks In (1996). A talented singer and dancer, Alexander has also had a notable stage career, winning a Tony Award in 1989 for his performance in the Broadway musical Jerome Robbins' Broadway. Alexander continues to work in television, often lending his voice to animated series and making guest appearances, while also participating in philanthropic efforts and political activism.

About the Character: Sarah Silverman played Rain Robinson, a 20th-century astronomer, in Star Trek: Voyager two-part episode "Future's End." Robinson discovers a strange signal from deep space, which leads her to encounter the Voyager crew, who have been thrown back in time. She assists Captain Janeway and the crew in preventing a temporal catastrophe. Silverman’s portrayal of Rain Robinson is energetic and intelligent, and her character forms a strong bond with Tom Paris. Her appearance in Star Trek was notable for blending her comedic background with a more serious science fiction role.
About the Guest:
Sarah Silverman is an American comedian, actress, and writer known for her bold, provocative humor that often addresses social and political issues, including race, gender, and religion. Her rise to fame began with her stand-up comedy, where her deadpan delivery and irreverent material gained her a devoted following. Silverman created and starred in The Sarah Silverman Program (2007-2010), a Comedy Central show that further established her unique comedic voice, blending absurdity with satirical commentary on contemporary issues. Her work has earned her several Emmy Award nominations, and she won two Primetime Emmys for her contributions to television.

In addition to her work in comedy, Silverman has had a successful acting career, appearing in films like Wreck-It Ralph (2012), A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014), and I Smile Back (2015), the latter of which showcased her ability to take on more serious, dramatic roles. She has also been an outspoken advocate for various political and social causes, using her platform to address issues such as women's rights, healthcare reform, and gun control. Silverman’s blend of sharp wit and social consciousness has made her one of the most influential comedians of her generation.

About the Character: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson guest-starred as The Champion, a Pendari fighter, in Star Trek: Voyager episode "Tsunkatse." In the episode, The Champion is a powerful gladiator who battles Seven of Nine in a combat sport called Tsunkatse. Johnson’s character is a skilled and brutal fighter, and his presence adds a physical, action-packed dynamic to the episode. This role was early in Johnson’s acting career, and his performance as The Champion highlighted his imposing screen presence and athletic ability, which would later define many of his roles.
About the Guest:
Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson is an American actor, producer, and former professional wrestler who has become one of the most recognizable and highest-paid stars in Hollywood. Johnson first gained fame as a charismatic WWE wrestler, where his larger-than-life persona and electrifying performances made him one of the biggest stars in the history of professional wrestling. Known for his catchphrases, including "Can you smell what The Rock is cooking?", Johnson became an international superstar and helped usher in the "Attitude Era" of the WWE in the late 1990s and early 2000s.

Transitioning to acting, Johnson quickly established himself as a major box-office draw, starring in action-packed films such as The Scorpion King (2002), Fast & Furious franchise, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle (2017), and Moana (2016), where he voiced the character Maui. His natural charisma, comedic timing, and imposing physicality have made him a beloved figure across multiple entertainment platforms. Johnson has also been involved in numerous charitable efforts and business ventures, including his own production company, Seven Bucks Productions, further expanding his influence in both entertainment and philanthropy.

About the Character: Vanessa Williams played Arandis, a Risan woman, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episode "Let He Who Is Without Sin...". Arandis is a former lover of Curzon Dax and works as a host on the pleasure planet Risa. She interacts with Jadzia Dax and Worf when they visit Risa, and her presence causes some tension between the couple. Williams’ portrayal of Arandis is lighthearted and warm, fitting the idyllic and hedonistic nature of Risa. Her appearance adds an interesting layer to Dax's backstory and the dynamic between Worf and Jadzia.
About the Guest:
Vanessa Williams is a multi-talented American actress, singer, and former beauty queen who made history as the first African-American woman to be crowned Miss America in 1983. Though she was forced to resign her title amid controversy, Williams quickly rebounded and launched a highly successful career in both music and acting. As a singer, she achieved commercial success with hits like "Save the Best for Last," "The Sweetest Days," and "Colors of the Wind," the latter of which was featured in the Disney animated film Pocahontas (1995). Her versatile vocal talents earned her several Grammy Award nominations and solidified her place in the music industry.

Williams transitioned into acting with great success, appearing in films like Eraser (1996) and Soul Food (1997) and gaining further acclaim for her role as Wilhelmina Slater on the hit TV series Ugly Betty (2006-2010). Her performance on Ugly Betty earned her multiple award nominations, including an Emmy. Williams has also made a mark on Broadway, starring in productions such as Into the Woods and Kiss of the Spider Woman. Her resilience and ability to thrive in both music and acting have made her one of the most respected and admired figures in entertainment.

About the Character: Ashley Judd played Ensign Robin Lefler, a young Starfleet officer, in Star Trek: The Next Generation episodes "Darmok" and "The Game." Lefler serves in the engineering department aboard the Enterprise-D and quickly forms a friendship with Wesley Crusher. In "The Game," Lefler and Wesley work together to uncover a conspiracy involving a mind-controlling device being distributed among the crew. Judd’s portrayal of Lefler is marked by her intelligence, resourcefulness, and quick thinking, making her a well-liked character in her brief appearances.
About the Guest:
Ashley Judd is an American actress and political activist known for her work in a variety of films throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, including Ruby in Paradise (1993), Heat (1995), Double Jeopardy (1999), and Kiss the Girls (1997). Judd's performances often portray strong, determined women, and her versatility has made her a well-regarded actress in both commercial blockbusters and critically acclaimed dramas. She has received several award nominations for her work in film and television, including a Golden Globe nomination for her role in Norma Jean & Marilyn (1996).

In addition to her acting career, Judd is a prominent political activist and humanitarian. She has been involved in global initiatives focusing on issues such as gender equality, sexual violence, and public health. Judd's outspoken advocacy for women's rights has brought her significant attention, particularly following her involvement in the #MeToo movement. Her ability to balance a successful acting career with her commitment to social justice has made her a powerful and influential voice both in Hollywood and beyond.

About the Character: F. Murray Abraham played Ru'afo, the villainous leader of the Son'a, in Star Trek: Insurrection. Ru'afo is obsessed with reclaiming his youth and leads a plan to harvest metaphasic radiation from the planet Ba'ku to extend his life. Abraham’s portrayal of Ru'afo is menacing, as his character is willing to sacrifice an entire planet’s inhabitants to achieve immortality. His performance, filled with intensity and anger, makes Ru'afo one of the more morally complex antagonists in the Star Trek films, as his motivations are driven by fear of aging and death.
About the Guest:
F. Murray Abraham is an American actor whose distinguished career spans theater, film, and television, but he is perhaps best known for his Academy Award-winning performance as Antonio Salieri in Amadeus (1984). Abraham’s portrayal of the conflicted and jealous composer earned him critical acclaim and solidified his place in film history. Prior to Amadeus, he had appeared in several supporting roles in films such as Scarface (1983) and All the President’s Men (1976), but it was his nuanced, emotionally charged performance as Salieri that made him a household name.

In addition to his film career, Abraham has had a notable presence in television and on stage. He has appeared in shows like Homeland, for which he won a Primetime Emmy Award, and in numerous stage productions, including his work with the Public Theater in New York. His ability to convey complex emotions and inner turmoil has made him one of the most respected character actors of his generation, and his later career has seen him continue to deliver memorable performances across multiple mediums.

About the Character: Kim Cattrall played Lieutenant Valeris, a Vulcan officer, in Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country. Valeris is a trusted protégé of Captain Spock and serves as the helmsman of the Enterprise-A. However, she is later revealed to be part of a conspiracy to prevent peace between the Klingon Empire and the Federation. Cattrall’s portrayal of Valeris is calculated and stoic, capturing the cool, logical nature of a Vulcan while also conveying the internal conflict of someone hiding a deep secret. Her betrayal of Spock and Kirk is a key emotional point in the film, and her character is pivotal to the plot's development.
About the Guest:
Kim Cattrall is a British-Canadian actress best known for her iconic role as Samantha Jones on the HBO series Sex and the City (1998-2004). As Samantha, Cattrall portrayed an empowered, sexually liberated woman, and her bold, comedic performance became one of the show’s highlights. Cattrall earned multiple Golden Globe and Emmy nominations for her work, winning a Golden Globe in 2003. Her portrayal of Samantha was celebrated for breaking taboos about women and sexuality on television, and the character became a cultural touchstone, inspiring a generation of women to embrace their independence.

Cattrall’s career extends beyond Sex and the City, with notable roles in films such as Police Academy (1984), Big Trouble in Little China (1986), and Mannequin (1987). She has also been involved in stage work, starring in productions like Private Lives and Antony and Cleopatra. In recent years, Cattrall has taken on more dramatic roles in television series like Sensitive Skin. Her ability to blend comedy with emotional depth has made her one of the most versatile actresses in Hollywood, with a career that spans several decades.

About the Character: Teri Hatcher made a brief appearance as an unnamed transporter chief in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "The Outrageous Okona." In the episode, she assists in transporting a visiting character, Okona, aboard the Enterprise-D. Though her role is small, Hatcher’s appearance is notable as she went on to achieve major fame with roles in Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman and Desperate Housewives.
About the Guest:
Teri Hatcher is an American actress best known for her role as Lois Lane on Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman (1993-1997) and as Susan Mayer on the hit television series Desperate Housewives (2004-2012). Hatcher’s portrayal of Lois Lane, the smart and feisty reporter, brought her significant attention in the 1990s, and she quickly became a fan favorite in the Superman universe. Her work on Desperate Housewives earned her widespread critical acclaim, including a Golden Globe Award and an Emmy nomination, as she played a lovable but often hapless single mother trying to navigate the complexities of suburban life.

In addition to her work on television, Hatcher has had a successful career in film, appearing in movies like Tomorrow Never Dies (1997) as a Bond girl and Spy Kids (2001). She has also lent her voice to animated projects, including Coraline (2009). Hatcher’s versatility as an actress, able to seamlessly transition between drama and comedy, has earned her a lasting presence in Hollywood, and her performances remain beloved by fans of both superhero lore and primetime drama.

About the Character: Tom Hardy portrayed Shinzon, the main antagonist in Star Trek: Nemesis. Shinzon is a human clone of Captain Jean-Luc Picard, raised in the Romulan mines and eventually becoming the leader of the Romulan fleet. His plan is to overthrow the Romulan Senate and destroy the Federation. Hardy’s portrayal of Shinzon showcases both the character’s vulnerability, as someone seeking identity and purpose, and his ruthlessness in his quest for power. This role came early in Hardy’s career, and his intense performance helped him gain attention for future major roles.
About the Guest:
Tom Hardy is a British actor known for his versatility and transformative performances across a wide range of genres. He first gained critical attention with his role in Bronson (2008), where he played the notorious British criminal Charles Bronson, a role that showcased his ability to fully immerse himself in physically demanding and psychologically complex characters. Hardy has since become a leading man in Hollywood, starring in major blockbusters such as Inception (2010), Mad Max: Fury Road (2015), The Revenant (2015), and the Venom franchise.

Hardy's performances are often characterized by their intensity and depth, whether he is playing a quiet but menacing antihero or a charismatic villain. He has been nominated for numerous awards, including an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role in The Revenant. His dedication to his craft and his willingness to take on physically and emotionally challenging roles have earned him a reputation as one of the most talented actors of his generation, with an ability to captivate audiences with his sheer presence on screen.

About the Character: Paul Winfield played Captain Terrell, commander of the USS Reliant, in Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan. Terrell is manipulated by Khan Noonien Singh, who uses parasitic creatures to control Terrell and Commander Chekov. Winfield’s portrayal of Terrell is tragic, as the character struggles to resist Khan’s influence before ultimately taking his own life rather than follow Khan’s orders to kill Captain Kirk. Winfield’s performance added emotional depth to the character’s internal battle.
About the Guest:
Paul Winfield was an American actor known for his powerful performances in both film and television. He received an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor for his role in Sounder (1972), where he portrayed a sharecropper struggling to keep his family together during the Great Depression. Winfield's performance in Sounder was widely praised for its emotional depth and dignity, making him one of the first African-American actors to receive significant critical acclaim in Hollywood. His film career also includes roles in The Terminator (1984) and Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982), where he played Captain Terrell.

Winfield's work in television was equally notable, earning him an Emmy Award for his portrayal of Martin Luther King Jr. in the miniseries King (1978) and another for his guest role on Picket Fences. His career was marked by his ability to bring gravitas and sensitivity to a wide variety of roles, often exploring themes of race, family, and social justice. Winfield’s legacy as a trailblazer for African-American actors in Hollywood remains significant, as his performances continue to resonate with audiences today.

About the Character: David Warner portrayed two notable roles in Star Trek. In Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country, Warner played Chancellor Gorkon, a Klingon leader seeking peace between the Klingon Empire and the Federation. His assassination becomes the catalyst for the film’s events, as Kirk and McCoy are framed for his murder. Warner’s dignified performance as Gorkon gave the character a sense of gravitas and honor. Warner also played Gul Madred, a Cardassian interrogator, in Star Trek: The Next Generation two-part episode "Chain of Command." Madred famously tortures Captain Picard, attempting to break him mentally by insisting there are “five lights” when Picard sees only four. Warner’s chilling performance as Madred made him one of the most memorable villains in Star Trek.
About the Guest:
David Warner was a British actor whose career spanned over five decades, with notable performances in film, television, and theater. Warner is perhaps best known for his roles in classic films such as The Omen (1976), Time After Time (1979), and Tron (1982). A versatile character actor, Warner has played both heroes and villains, often bringing a distinctive intensity and intelligence to his performances. He also became a familiar face in genre films, making appearances in several Star Trek films and Doctor Who.

In addition to his film work, Warner had an extensive career in television, with roles in popular series such as Twin Peaks and Titanic (1997). He is also a renowned Shakespearean actor, having performed with the Royal Shakespeare Company in some of the most acclaimed productions of the 1960s. Warner's ability to command the stage and screen with his authoritative presence made him a beloved figure in both mainstream and genre entertainment.

About the Character: James Cromwell portrayed Zefram Cochrane, the inventor of warp drive, in Star Trek: First Contact. Cochrane is initially depicted as a reluctant hero, far from the idealized version of himself revered by future generations. He is more interested in fame and fortune than in the groundbreaking implications of his warp flight, but over the course of the film, he rises to the occasion and makes history. Cromwell’s performance adds complexity to the character, as Cochrane must come to terms with his legacy and the responsibility he holds for the future of humanity’s space exploration.
About the Guest:
James Cromwell is an American actor known for his performances in both film and television, often portraying authoritative or morally complex characters. Cromwell gained widespread recognition for his Oscar-nominated role as Farmer Hoggett in Babe (1995), where his understated and heartfelt performance won over audiences. His versatility as an actor is evident in his roles across genres, including The Green Mile (1999), L.A. Confidential (1997), and The Queen (2006). Cromwell is also known for his work in science fiction, particularly in Star Trek: First Contact (1996) as Zefram Cochrane, the inventor of warp drive.

Beyond his film career, Cromwell has made a significant impact on television, appearing in critically acclaimed series like Six Feet Under and The Young Pope. An outspoken advocate for animal rights and environmental causes, Cromwell’s activism has also been a defining feature of his public life. His ability to tackle a wide range of characters, from kindly figures to corrupt politicians, has made him one of the most respected and enduring actors in Hollywood.

About the Character: Paul Sorvino played Dr. Nikolai Rozhenko, Worf’s human foster brother, in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "Homeward." Rozhenko, a cultural observer on a doomed planet, defies the Prime Directive by attempting to save the native population from extinction. His actions create conflict with his brother Worf and the crew of the Enterprise-D. Sorvino’s portrayal of Rozhenko adds a moral complexity to the episode, as his character’s motivations stem from compassion but challenge Starfleet’s core principles.
About the Guest:
Paul Sorvino was an American actor, opera singer, and sculptor best known for his roles in both film and television, particularly in mafia films. He gained widespread fame for his portrayal of mob boss Paulie Cicero in Martin Scorsese’s Goodfellas (1990). Sorvino’s performance as the calm yet menacing Paulie Cicero became iconic, cementing his status as a major player in crime dramas. His ability to portray figures of authority extended beyond the criminal underworld, as he frequently played law enforcement officers and high-ranking officials in films such as Nixon (1995) and The Rocketeer (1991).

In addition to his work in film, Sorvino had a successful television career, appearing in series like Law & Order, where he played Sergeant Phil Cerreta. Beyond acting, Sorvino was a classically trained opera singer and a sculptor, adding to his artistic range. His daughter, Mira Sorvino, is also a renowned actress, and he was a proud supporter of her career. Sorvino’s lasting impact on the world of cinema, especially in the gangster genre, has left an enduring legacy.

About the Character: Kirstie Alley portrayed Lieutenant Saavik, a Vulcan Starfleet officer, in Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan. Saavik is a protégé of Spock and serves as a cadet aboard the USS Enterprise during the battle with Khan. Alley’s portrayal of Saavik is notable for blending the Vulcan traits of logic and control with hints of emotional depth. Saavik plays a key role in the film’s events, learning the difficult realities of command and loss as she witnesses the death of Spock. Alley’s performance helped establish Saavik as a memorable character in Star Trek lore.
About the Guest:
Kirstie Alley was an American actress best known for her role as Rebecca Howe on the long-running sitcom Cheers (1987-1993). Taking over from Shelley Long, Alley’s character brought a fresh dynamic to the show, and her comedic timing earned her a Primetime Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for her performance. Her portrayal of Rebecca Howe as a smart, ambitious woman with a neurotic edge made her a fan favorite and helped Cheers maintain its status as one of the most beloved sitcoms of all time.

In addition to Cheers, Alley had a successful film career, starring in movies like Look Who’s Talking (1989) and its sequels, Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982), where she played Lieutenant Saavik, and Drop Dead Gorgeous (1999). Alley also headlined her own sitcom, Veronica’s Closet (1997-2000), and participated in reality television later in her career. Her versatile talent for both comedy and drama allowed her to stay in the spotlight for decades, and she became a prominent figure in both film and television.

About the Character: Kirsten Dunst appeared as Hedril, a young alien girl, in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "Dark Page." Hedril is involved in a telepathic link with Counselor Troi’s mother, Lwaxana Troi, which inadvertently brings up repressed memories of Lwaxana’s deceased daughter. Dunst’s role is small, but her performance as Hedril adds an emotional layer to the episode’s exploration of grief and memory.
About the Guest:
Kirsten Dunst is an American actress who has been a major figure in Hollywood since childhood. She made her film debut in New York Stories (1989), but her breakout role came in Interview with the Vampire (1994), where her performance as the child vampire Claudia earned her critical acclaim and a Golden Globe nomination. Dunst continued to act in films throughout her teenage years, starring in Jumanji (1995) and Bring It On (2000), before transitioning to more mature roles in films like Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004) and Sofia Coppola's Marie Antoinette (2006).

Dunst is perhaps best known to modern audiences for her portrayal of Mary Jane Watson in Sam Raimi’s Spider-Man trilogy (2002-2007), where she played the love interest of Peter Parker. Her ability to balance both mainstream blockbusters and indie films has made her a versatile and respected actress. In recent years, Dunst has continued to earn praise for her roles in television, particularly in Fargo (2015), where she received an Emmy nomination for her performance. Her longevity in the industry is a testament to her talent and adaptability as a performer.

About the Character: Brock Peters played two important roles in Star Trek. He first portrayed Admiral Cartwright in Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home and Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country. Cartwright is a high-ranking Starfleet officer who becomes embroiled in a conspiracy to prevent peace with the Klingons in The Undiscovered Country. Peters’ portrayal of Cartwright is authoritative and later, morally conflicted. Peters also portrayed Joseph Sisko, father of Captain Benjamin Sisko, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. As a New Orleans restaurant owner, Joseph Sisko represents family, tradition, and Earth-bound roots in contrast to his son’s life in space. Peters’ warm and grounded portrayal of Joseph Sisko adds emotional depth to Benjamin Sisko’s character arc throughout the series.
About the Guest:
Brock Peters was an American actor best known for his powerful performance as Tom Robinson, the wrongfully accused Black man, in To Kill a Mockingbird (1962). Peters’ portrayal of Robinson, a man accused of raping a white woman in the racially charged South, remains one of the most moving and poignant performances in cinematic history. His work in the film earned him widespread acclaim, and he continued to play socially conscious roles throughout his career, often depicting characters who confronted issues of race and injustice.

In addition to his work in film, Peters had a notable presence in television and theater. He appeared in Star Trek as Admiral Cartwright in Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986) and Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country (1991) and played Joseph Sisko, father of Captain Benjamin Sisko, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. Peters also worked as a voice actor and had a strong career on Broadway, with roles in plays like Lost in the Stars. His powerful voice and commanding presence made him a beloved figure in the entertainment industry, and he was a trailblazer for African-American actors in Hollywood.

About the Character: Catherine Hicks played Dr. Gillian Taylor, a marine biologist, in Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home. Dr. Taylor works at the Cetacean Institute in the 20th century and aids Kirk and his crew in their mission to save humpback whales, which are essential to Earth’s survival in the future. Hicks’ portrayal of Dr. Taylor is spunky and determined, as her character navigates the bizarre circumstances of time travelers and their futuristic technology. Her chemistry with Captain Kirk and her passion for marine life make her a central figure in the film’s story.
About the Guest:
Catherine Hicks is an American actress best known for her role as Annie Camden on the long-running television series 7th Heaven (1996-2007). As the matriarch of a large, religious family, Hicks became a household name, and her portrayal of a nurturing, strong-willed mother earned her critical acclaim. The show’s family-friendly appeal and moral lessons made it a staple of 1990s and 2000s television, and Hicks’ performance was central to its success.

Before her television fame, Hicks had a successful film career, with notable roles such as Dr. Gillian Taylor in Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986), where she played a marine biologist who helps Captain Kirk and his crew save humpback whales. Her chemistry with William Shatner and her character’s pivotal role in the film made her a fan favorite in the Star Trek franchise. Throughout her career, Hicks has balanced film, television, and stage work, showcasing her versatility as an actress across multiple genres.

About the Character: Frank Langella played Minister Jaro, a Bajoran leader, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episodes "The Homecoming," "The Circle," and "The Siege." Jaro is a prominent political figure who seeks power through his involvement with a militant faction called The Circle, which tries to overthrow the Bajoran provisional government. Langella’s portrayal of Jaro is subtle and manipulative, as he presents himself as a concerned leader while secretly orchestrating a coup. His performance adds intrigue and complexity to the political landscape of Bajor during the early seasons of Deep Space Nine.
About the Guest:
Frank Langella is an American actor whose career spans over five decades, with a body of work that includes both stage and screen performances. He is particularly well-known for his portrayal of Richard Nixon in the play Frost/Nixon (2006), a role he reprised in the film adaptation (2008), earning him an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor. Langella’s performance as Nixon was widely praised for its depth and complexity, portraying the former president as both a formidable politician and a tragic figure. His ability to bring gravitas and nuance to his roles has made him one of the most respected actors in the industry.

Langella’s diverse career also includes standout performances in films such as Dracula (1979), The Ninth Gate (1999), and Good Night, and Good Luck (2005). He has won multiple Tony Awards for his work on Broadway and remains a fixture in the theater world. Known for his powerful screen presence and commanding voice, Langella continues to take on roles that challenge him, both as a performer and as a storyteller, securing his legacy as one of the great actors of his generation.

About the Character: Tony Todd played two major roles in Star Trek. He portrayed Kurn, Worf’s brother, in Star Trek: The Next Generation and Deep Space Nine. Kurn struggles with his family’s dishonor and his own personal conflicts, often serving as a foil to Worf’s more controlled nature. Todd’s portrayal of Kurn is intense and emotionally charged, making Kurn a tragic figure in Klingon culture. Todd also played the adult Jake Sisko in the acclaimed Deep Space Nine episode "The Visitor." In this episode, an older Jake reflects on his life and the loss of his father, Benjamin Sisko, in a temporal anomaly. Todd’s performance as Jake is deeply emotional, capturing the profound impact of losing a parent and the lengths one might go to for the chance to bring them back.
About the Guest:
Tony Todd is an American actor best known for his role as the terrifying title character in the Candyman horror franchise. His deep voice and imposing stature made him a natural fit for the horror genre, and his portrayal of the vengeful, hook-handed spirit in Candyman (1992) became iconic. Todd reprised the role in multiple sequels, cementing his status as one of the most recognizable faces in horror. His ability to evoke both fear and sympathy for his characters has made him a standout performer in a genre known for its often one-dimensional villains.

In addition to Candyman, Todd has had a prolific career in both film and television. He appeared in The Crow (1994), Final Destination (2000), and several Star Trek series, where he played Worf’s brother, Kurn, and the adult Jake Sisko in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. Todd’s versatility as an actor has allowed him to cross genres, from horror to science fiction to drama, and his contributions to film and television have made him a beloved figure, particularly in genre filmmaking.

About the Character: Daniel Dae Kim appeared as Gotana-Retz, an alien scientist, in Star Trek: Voyager episode "Blink of an Eye." Gotana-Retz lives on a planet where time moves much faster than on Voyager, allowing his civilization to develop rapidly while Voyager remains in orbit. Kim’s character plays a key role in the episode as he communicates with the Voyager crew and helps them understand his planet’s unique temporal phenomenon. His performance adds a sense of wonder and discovery to the episode.
About the Guest:
Daniel Dae Kim is a Korean-American actor best known for his role as Jin-Soo Kwon on the hit television series Lost (2004-2010). Kim’s portrayal of Jin, a Korean man stranded on a mysterious island with his wife Sun, helped break down stereotypes about Asian characters on American television. Over the course of the series, his character evolved from a stoic, seemingly controlling husband to a deeply emotional and heroic figure. His performance on Lost earned him widespread recognition and cemented his place in pop culture.

In addition to Lost, Kim starred in the reboot of Hawaii Five-0 (2010-2017), where he played Chin Ho Kelly, further solidifying his status as a leading man on American television. He has also been involved in advocacy for greater representation of Asian Americans in Hollywood and has taken on more producing roles to help bring diverse stories to the screen. Kim’s impact on both television and the larger entertainment industry has made him one of the most influential Asian-American actors working today.

About the Character: John Rhys-Davies portrayed Leonardo da Vinci in Star Trek: Voyager. Da Vinci appears as a holographic character in several episodes, including "Scorpion, Part I" and "Concerning Flight." In these episodes, Captain Janeway often visits the holodeck to consult with da Vinci, using his perspective on art and science to help her solve complex problems. Rhys-Davies brings warmth and intelligence to the character, portraying da Vinci as a mentor figure for Janeway. His portrayal blends historical gravitas with moments of lightheartedness, making da Vinci a unique addition to Voyager’s cast of holodeck characters.
About the Guest:
John Rhys-Davies is a Welsh actor best known for his roles as Gimli in The Lord of the Rings trilogy (2001-2003) and as Sallah in the Indiana Jones franchise. Rhys-Davies’ portrayal of Gimli, the dwarf warrior, became iconic as part of the critically acclaimed Lord of the Rings films, which were lauded for their ensemble cast and groundbreaking special effects. His performance as Sallah, the loyal Egyptian friend of Indiana Jones, in Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981) and Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989), remains one of his most beloved roles.

Rhys-Davies has also had a successful career in television, appearing in shows like Sliders (1995-2000) and voicing characters in animated series. His commanding voice and physical presence have made him a favorite in both live-action and voice acting roles. Throughout his long career, Rhys-Davies has been known for his ability to bring a sense of grandeur and gravitas to his characters, particularly in fantasy and adventure genres, making him a standout actor in the world of genre entertainment.

About the Character: Clint Howard portrayed Balok, the childlike commander of the First Federation ship Fesarius, in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "The Corbomite Maneuver." Balok initially appears as a menacing alien, but it is later revealed that the fearsome image was a ruse, and Balok himself is a small, friendly alien who tests the crew's reaction to danger. Howard’s portrayal of Balok, despite his young age at the time, is memorable for its eerie calmness and playful innocence, contributing to one of the most iconic episodes of the original series.
About the Guest:
Clint Howard is an American actor known for his distinctive looks and ability to play quirky, memorable characters in both film and television. The younger brother of director Ron Howard, Clint began acting at a young age, appearing in classic shows like The Andy Griffith Show and Star Trek: The Original Series, where he famously played the alien child Balok in the episode "The Corbomite Maneuver." Throughout his career, Clint has appeared in a wide range of roles, often playing oddball characters, which has made him a cult favorite in genre films.

Howard has had a long and varied career, with appearances in films directed by his brother Ron, such as Apollo 13 (1995) and How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000), as well as cult classics like Ice Cream Man (1995). His ability to take on small but memorable roles has made him a beloved character actor, especially in the worlds of science fiction and horror. Howard’s longevity in the industry, coupled with his offbeat charm, has earned him a dedicated following among fans of genre entertainment.

About the Character: Ben Vereen appeared as Edward La Forge, the father of Geordi La Forge, in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "Interface." Edward La Forge is a Starfleet exobiologist who is reported missing in a shuttle accident. The episode focuses on Geordi's struggle with the loss of his mother and the emotional turmoil it causes. Vereen’s portrayal is brief but adds depth to Geordi’s backstory, showing the familial ties that shape his character.
About the Guest:
Ben Vereen is an American actor, dancer, and singer known for his work on Broadway and in film and television. Vereen gained fame for his roles in musical theater, particularly for his Tony Award-winning performance in Pippin (1972), where he showcased his extraordinary talent as a dancer and performer. His versatility as an entertainer has made him one of the most respected figures in musical theater, with notable performances in productions like Jesus Christ Superstar and Chicago. Vereen’s magnetic stage presence and his ability to convey deep emotion through song and dance have earned him widespread acclaim.

In addition to his stage work, Vereen has had a successful career in television and film. He is perhaps best known for his role as Chicken George in the landmark television miniseries Roots (1977), which brought him widespread recognition and an Emmy nomination. Vereen has also appeared in a variety of other TV shows and films, continuing to showcase his wide-ranging talents. His contributions to the world of entertainment, both on stage and screen, have made him a beloved figure in the performing arts.

About the Character: Ronny Cox played Captain Edward Jellico in Star Trek: The Next Generation two-part episode "Chain of Command." Jellico temporarily replaces Captain Picard as commander of the Enterprise-D while Picard is on a secret mission. Jellico's leadership style is strict, by-the-book, and often clashes with the established crew dynamic. Cox's portrayal of Jellico brings a tension-filled shift in command to the series, as he demands complete control and respect from the crew, leading to a memorable power struggle with Commander Riker.
About the Guest:
Ronny Cox is an American actor and musician best known for his roles in both film and television. He made his film debut in the 1972 classic Deliverance, where he played Drew Ballinger, one of the men involved in a harrowing survival journey through the wilderness. Cox’s performance in the film, particularly his iconic dueling banjo scene, helped establish him as a versatile actor capable of handling complex roles. He went on to appear in numerous films throughout the 1970s and 1980s, including RoboCop (1987) and Total Recall (1990), where he often played authoritative or villainous characters.

In addition to his film work, Cox has had a notable career in television, appearing in shows like St. Elsewhere and Star Trek: The Next Generation, where he played Captain Edward Jellico, a no-nonsense Starfleet officer whose leadership style clashed with the Enterprise crew. Outside of acting, Cox is also an accomplished musician, having released several albums as a singer-songwriter. His dual careers in acting and music have allowed him to maintain a long and diverse presence in the entertainment industry.

About the Character: Louise Fletcher portrayed Kai Winn Adami, the ambitious Bajoran religious leader, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. Winn is a complex and often antagonistic figure, seeking political and religious power over Bajor while presenting herself as a pious servant of the Prophets. Fletcher’s portrayal of Winn is nuanced, capturing the character's manipulative, self-serving nature while maintaining a facade of humility. Her presence as a recurring adversary to Captain Sisko and Major Kira adds depth to the show’s exploration of faith, politics, and leadership.
About the Guest:
Louise Fletcher was an American actress best known for her Academy Award-winning performance as Nurse Ratched in One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest (1975). Her portrayal of the cold, authoritarian nurse who exerts psychological control over the patients in a mental institution became iconic, earning her both an Oscar and a Golden Globe for Best Actress. Fletcher’s performance as Nurse Ratched remains one of the most memorable villainous roles in cinematic history and has had a lasting impact on pop culture. The character was recently revisited in the Netflix series Ratched (2020), demonstrating the enduring influence of Fletcher’s portrayal.

Beyond One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest, Fletcher had a long career in film and television. She appeared in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine as the duplicitous religious leader Kai Winn, a role that allowed her to explore another complex and morally ambiguous character. Fletcher's ability to portray strong, manipulative women with a subtle intensity made her a standout performer across various genres, and her work in film and television continues to be celebrated.

About the Character: Before his rise to fame, Jeffrey Dean Morgan appeared as a Xindi Reptilian in Star Trek: Enterprise episode "Carpenter Street." His character is part of a Xindi plot to use a biological weapon against humanity, and he interacts with Captain Archer during a time travel mission to stop the Xindi from unleashing a deadly virus. Although heavily disguised under prosthetics, Morgan’s intense performance as a ruthless alien operative adds tension to the episode.
About the Guest:
Jeffrey Dean Morgan is an American actor best known for his role as Negan in The Walking Dead (2016-present). Morgan’s portrayal of the charismatic yet brutal villain has become one of the most talked-about performances on the show, earning him a devoted fan base and critical acclaim. His ability to bring charm and menace to the role of Negan has made him one of the most memorable antagonists in modern television, and his character has become an iconic part of The Walking Dead franchise.

In addition to The Walking Dead, Morgan has had a successful career in both film and television. He played the tragic character of Denny Duquette in Grey’s Anatomy (2006-2009), which earned him widespread recognition, and has appeared in films like Watchmen (2009), where he played The Comedian. Morgan’s rugged good looks and versatile acting abilities have allowed him to take on a wide range of roles, from romantic leads to hardened antiheroes, making him one of the most sought-after actors in Hollywood today.

About the Character: Phil Morris portrayed Remata'Klan, a Jem'Hadar soldier, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episode "Rocks and Shoals." Remata'Klan is a loyal but honorable Jem'Hadar who serves under the Vorta Keevan. Despite being a genetically engineered soldier bred for obedience, Remata'Klan displays a sense of dignity and ethics, even as he follows orders that will ultimately lead to his death. Morris’s performance brings complexity to the character, showcasing the internal conflict between loyalty and morality.
About the Guest:
Phil Morris is an American actor best known for his roles in both live-action television and voice acting. He gained widespread recognition for his portrayal of Jackie Chiles, the fast-talking lawyer, on the hit sitcom Seinfeld (1993-1998). Modeled after real-life attorney Johnnie Cochran, Morris’ performance as Chiles was memorable for his comedic timing and exaggerated delivery, making the character one of the most beloved guest stars on the show. His work on Seinfeld helped establish him as a talented comedic actor.

In addition to his comedic work, Morris has had a successful career in science fiction and voice acting. He appeared in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine and Star Trek: Voyager, playing Jem’Hadar and Kreetassan characters, and has voiced characters in animated series such as Justice League and The Secret Saturdays. His versatility as an actor has allowed him to work across genres, making him a familiar face to both science fiction fans and mainstream audiences.

About the Character: William Sadler played Luthor Sloan, the shadowy operative of Section 31, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. Sloan is a high-ranking officer in the covert organization, which operates outside of Starfleet’s jurisdiction to protect the Federation by any means necessary. Sadler’s portrayal of Sloan is chilling and calculating, as he manipulates and recruits Dr. Bashir into the morally questionable world of Section 31. Sloan’s appearance raises ethical questions about the lengths to which a society will go for its own security, with Sadler’s performance adding depth to the franchise’s exploration of espionage and covert operations.
About the Guest:
William Sadler is an American actor known for his work in both film and television, often portraying tough or morally complex characters. He gained widespread recognition for his role as Colonel Stuart, the main antagonist in Die Hard 2 (1990), where his intense performance solidified his reputation as a compelling villain. Sadler has also made a significant impact in the realm of science fiction, particularly for his portrayal of Death in Bill & Ted’s Bogus Journey (1991) and Bill & Ted Face the Music (2020). His ability to blend menace with humor made his depiction of Death a fan favorite.

In addition to his work in film, Sadler has had a successful television career. He starred as Sheriff Jim Valenti in the popular sci-fi series Roswell (1999-2002) and played the enigmatic Luthor Sloan, head of the covert organization Section 31, in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. His versatility has allowed him to take on a wide variety of roles, from villains to sympathetic characters, across genres ranging from action to drama to science fiction. Sadler’s commitment to his craft and his ability to inhabit complex roles have earned him a long-lasting career in Hollywood.

About the Character: Lawrence Tierney portrayed Cyrus Redblock, a holodeck character based on a 1940s crime boss, in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "The Big Goodbye." Redblock is a ruthless, mobster-type figure in a Dixon Hill holodeck simulation, and he becomes confused when he starts to realize that his world may not be real. Tierney’s performance as Redblock brings a menacing presence to the character, as his attempts to gain control of the situation escalate into violence.
About the Guest:
Lawrence Tierney was an American actor known for playing tough-guy roles, particularly in film noir during the 1940s and 1950s. His breakout role came in Dillinger (1945), where he portrayed the infamous gangster John Dillinger. Tierney’s rugged persona and natural intensity made him a go-to actor for roles that required a hard-edged, often violent character. Throughout his career, he appeared in numerous crime dramas and B-movies, often typecast as the villain due to his imposing presence and gruff voice.

In his later years, Tierney experienced a resurgence in popularity with roles in films like Reservoir Dogs (1992), where he played Joe Cabot, the leader of the criminal gang at the center of the film. His career was marked by off-screen controversy, including run-ins with the law, which only added to his tough-guy image. Despite his personal struggles, Tierney remained a memorable figure in Hollywood, leaving behind a legacy as one of film noir’s most iconic tough guys.

About the Character: James Sloyan played Dr. Mora Pol, the Bajoran scientist who first studied Odo, in several episodes of Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. Dr. Mora is essentially a father figure to Odo, as he was the one who discovered Odo's abilities as a shapeshifter. Their relationship is strained, as Odo resents the experiments Dr. Mora conducted on him in the name of science. Sloyan’s portrayal of Dr. Mora is both paternal and clinical, adding emotional complexity to Odo’s backstory and their eventual reconciliation.
About the Guest:
James Sloyan is an American actor known for his character roles in both television and film. Sloyan is perhaps best known for his work in Star Trek, where he portrayed several memorable characters, including Dr. Mora Pol in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine and the future Alexander Rozhenko in Star Trek: The Next Generation. His performance as Mora Pol, Odo’s mentor, added emotional depth to Odo’s backstory, exploring the complicated relationship between creator and creation. Sloyan’s ability to bring gravitas and complexity to his roles made him a standout in the Star Trek franchise.

In addition to his work in Star Trek, Sloyan has appeared in numerous television series, including The Love Boat, Hawaii Five-O, and MacGyver. His versatility as an actor has allowed him to tackle a wide range of characters, from scientists and military figures to more nuanced, emotional roles. Sloyan has also worked extensively as a voice actor, lending his distinctive voice to commercials and animated series. His longevity in the industry and his memorable performances have made him a respected figure in both television and film.

About the Character: William Marshall portrayed Dr. Richard Daystrom in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "The Ultimate Computer." Daystrom is the inventor of the M-5 multitronic computer, designed to replace starship crews with artificial intelligence. However, the M-5 becomes dangerously unstable, leading to tragic consequences. Marshall’s portrayal of Daystrom is intense, as the character grapples with the breakdown of his creation and his own mental deterioration. His performance adds gravitas to the episode’s exploration of the ethics of technology and artificial intelligence.
About the Guest:
William Marshall was an American actor, opera singer, and director, best known for his deep voice and commanding stage presence. He gained fame for his portrayal of Dr. Richard Daystrom in Star Trek: The Original Series, where he played a brilliant but troubled scientist who creates the M-5 computer. However, Marshall’s most iconic role came in the 1970s when he played the lead character in the blaxploitation horror films Blacula (1972) and its sequel, Scream Blacula Scream (1973). His portrayal of the tragic vampire prince brought dignity and gravitas to a genre typically known for its camp.

Marshall’s career extended beyond film and television, as he was also a prominent stage actor, particularly known for his Shakespearean performances. He played Othello on several occasions, both on Broadway and in regional theaters, earning acclaim for his interpretation of the role. Marshall’s deep, resonant voice also led to a successful career as a voice actor in animated series and commercials. His influence as a trailblazing African-American actor in both film and theater remains a significant part of his legacy.

About the Character: Carolyn Seymour appeared as a Romulan Commander in several episodes of Star Trek: The Next Generation. Her character is a high-ranking officer in the Romulan Star Empire, involved in diplomatic tensions and confrontations with the Federation. Seymour’s portrayal is authoritative and sharp, embodying the cunning and strategic nature of the Romulans. Her presence adds weight to the episodes in which she appears, showcasing the complex political dynamics between the Federation and the Romulan Empire.
About the Guest:
Carolyn Seymour is a British actress known for her work in science fiction and drama, with notable roles in Star Trek and Survivors (1975-1977), a British post-apocalyptic series. In Star Trek, Seymour appeared in Star Trek: The Next Generation as two different Romulan commanders and as a member of the alien Q Continuum. Her portrayal of cold, calculating Romulan officials showcased her ability to play complex, authoritative characters, and she became a familiar face in the Star Trek universe.

Outside of Star Trek, Seymour has had a diverse acting career, with appearances in shows like Quantum Leap, Murder, She Wrote, and ER. She is also known for her voice acting work, lending her voice to video games such as the Mass Effect series. With her distinctive voice and commanding presence, Seymour has carved out a niche for herself in science fiction and drama, earning respect from fans and critics alike for her consistent and versatile performances.

About the Character: Gary Graham played Ambassador Soval, the Vulcan ambassador to Earth, in Star Trek: Enterprise. Soval is initially skeptical of humanity’s role in space exploration, often coming into conflict with Captain Archer and Starfleet’s leadership. However, over the course of the series, Soval grows to respect humans and their potential. Graham’s portrayal of Soval is reserved and logical, consistent with Vulcan characteristics, but also shows the ambassador’s gradual shift in perspective and his growing appreciation for human perseverance.
About the Guest:
Gary Graham is an American actor best known for his role as Detective Matthew Sikes in the television series Alien Nation (1989-1990) and for portraying Ambassador Soval, a Vulcan diplomat, in Star Trek: Enterprise. In Alien Nation, Graham’s character worked alongside an alien partner in a futuristic Los Angeles, dealing with issues of prejudice and crime. His portrayal of Sikes brought both toughness and vulnerability to the character, and the show became a cult favorite, spawning TV movies and a dedicated fan base.

Graham’s role as Ambassador Soval in Star Trek: Enterprise showcased his ability to play a more measured, intellectual character. As a Vulcan, Soval was initially critical of human space exploration but eventually came to respect Captain Archer and Starfleet’s efforts. Graham’s work in Star Trek extended to several fan projects and non-canon productions, demonstrating his continued connection to the franchise. Beyond science fiction, Graham has appeared in numerous television series and films, making him a versatile actor with a long and varied career.

About the Character: Alan Ruck portrayed Captain John Harriman, commander of the USS Enterprise-B, in Star Trek: Generations. Harriman takes command of the new Enterprise during its maiden voyage, but when the ship encounters a distress call, Harriman is unprepared for the crisis. His inexperience and hesitation lead to the death of Captain Kirk (temporarily). Ruck’s portrayal of Harriman as a young, nervous captain thrust into an unexpected situation brings tension to the film’s opening scenes, and his character’s arc reflects the pressures of living up to the legacy of his ship’s predecessors.
About the Guest:
Alan Ruck is an American actor best known for his role as Cameron Frye in the iconic 1986 film Ferris Bueller's Day Off. As the neurotic best friend of the carefree Ferris, Ruck’s portrayal of Cameron provided much of the emotional depth and humor of the film. Cameron’s arc, from anxiety-ridden teenager to someone who stands up to his domineering father, resonated with audiences, and the role became one of the most memorable in 1980s teen cinema. Despite the film’s success, Ruck found himself typecast for several years in similar roles.

Ruck experienced a career resurgence with his portrayal of Connor Roy, the eldest son in the dysfunctional Roy family, on HBO’s critically acclaimed series Succession (2018-present). His portrayal of the eccentric, somewhat clueless eldest sibling has earned him widespread praise and introduced him to a new generation of fans. Between these roles, Ruck has appeared in numerous films and TV shows, including Spin City, Twister (1996), and Star Trek: Generations (1994), where he played Captain John Harriman of the USS Enterprise-B.

About the Character: John Tesh, the musician and former host of Entertainment Tonight, made a cameo as an unnamed Klingon in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "The Icarus Factor." Tesh’s role is brief and mostly unrecognizable, as he is heavily disguised under Klingon makeup during a scene where Worf participates in a Klingon rite of ascension. While his appearance is minor, it is a fun nod for fans familiar with his work outside of Star Trek.
About the Guest:
