John Tesh is an American musician, composer, and television personality who is best known for his work as a co-host on Entertainment Tonight (1986-1996) and for his successful career as a pianist and composer of contemporary instrumental music. Tesh gained fame through his work on Entertainment Tonight, where his charisma and knowledge of the entertainment industry made him a household name. His work in television extended to hosting various specials and award shows, further solidifying his place in American pop culture.

Beyond his television work, Tesh has enjoyed a successful music career, releasing several albums of new-age and instrumental music. His "Live at Red Rocks" concert, which aired on PBS, was a huge success, leading to a long-running career in music. Tesh is also known for composing the theme music for NBC’s NBA on NBC broadcasts, which became iconic in the 1990s. While his acting appearances are rare, Tesh made a brief cameo as an unnamed Klingon in Star Trek: The Next Generation, showcasing his connection to pop culture in a different medium.

About the Character: Eric Bana portrayed Nero, the Romulan antagonist in Star Trek (2009). Nero is a vengeful miner from the future whose home planet, Romulus, was destroyed in a supernova. Blaming the Federation and especially Ambassador Spock for failing to prevent the disaster, Nero travels back in time to exact revenge by attacking the Federation in the past. Bana’s portrayal of Nero is intense and emotionally charged, with the character’s grief and rage driving him to wreak havoc across the timeline. Nero’s actions create the alternate universe that forms the basis of the "Kelvin Timeline" in the Star Trek reboot films.
About the Guest:
Eric Bana is an Australian actor who first gained attention for his role in the darkly comedic Australian film Chopper (2000), where he portrayed real-life criminal Mark "Chopper" Read. Bana’s transformative performance, which involved a significant physical transformation, earned him widespread acclaim and launched his international career. Following Chopper, Bana appeared in several major Hollywood productions, including Black Hawk Down (2001) and Hulk (2003), where he played Bruce Banner in the first film adaptation of the Marvel superhero.

Bana’s career took another leap forward when he portrayed the vengeful Romulan Nero in J.J. Abrams’ Star Trek (2009), the villain responsible for the creation of the alternate timeline known as the Kelvin Timeline. His portrayal of Nero brought intensity and emotional depth to the role, marking him as a memorable antagonist in the Star Trek reboot. In addition to his work in action and science fiction, Bana has continued to diversify his career with roles in films such as Munich (2005) and The Time Traveler’s Wife (2009), proving his range as a leading man.

About the Character: Brad Dourif played Lon Suder, a psychopathic Betazoid crewman, in Star Trek: Voyager episodes "Meld" and "Basics, Part I & II." Suder is introduced as a violent murderer aboard the USS Voyager, who is eventually rehabilitated by Tuvok. Despite his efforts to change, Suder struggles with his violent impulses, especially as a Betazoid with heightened emotions. Dourif’s portrayal is chilling and complex, capturing Suder’s inner conflict as he grapples with his dark nature. His character’s ultimate sacrifice to help save the ship adds a redemptive arc to Suder’s otherwise disturbing presence.
About the Guest:
Brad Dourif is an American actor known for his distinctive voice and intense performances, often in offbeat or villainous roles. He first gained widespread recognition for his Oscar-nominated performance as Billy Bibbit in One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest (1975), where his portrayal of a mentally troubled patient captivated audiences. This breakout role launched Dourif’s long and varied career, where he often played eccentric or unsettling characters, including the voice of Chucky in the Child’s Play franchise, a role that cemented his place in horror film history.

Dourif has also had notable roles in major franchises, including his portrayal of the sadistic Gríma Wormtongue in The Lord of the Rings trilogy and as the unstable crewman Lon Suder in Star Trek: Voyager. His work in both film and television has earned him a reputation as one of Hollywood’s most versatile and unique character actors, capable of bringing depth and complexity to roles in genres ranging from horror to fantasy to drama.

About the Character: Robert Lansing played Gary Seven in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Assignment: Earth." Gary Seven is a human agent working for an advanced alien species that has sent him to Earth to ensure the planet’s survival through a turbulent period in history. Posing as a mysterious figure with advanced technology, Seven partners with Roberta Lincoln to prevent a missile crisis from sparking a global catastrophe. Lansing’s portrayal of Gary Seven is calm, confident, and secretive, and his character was intended to lead a potential spin-off series that ultimately did not materialize.
About the Guest:
Robert Lansing was an American actor known for his roles in both television and film, particularly for playing tough, authoritative figures. He gained widespread recognition for his portrayal of Gary Seven, a human agent working for an alien species, in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Assignment: Earth." Although the episode was intended to serve as a backdoor pilot for a spin-off series that never materialized, Lansing’s performance as the enigmatic and suave Gary Seven left a lasting impression on Star Trek fans.

In addition to his work on Star Trek, Lansing appeared in numerous television series, including 12 O'Clock High, where he played Brigadier General Frank Savage, and The Equalizer. He had a commanding screen presence that often made him the go-to actor for roles requiring gravitas and leadership. Lansing’s ability to bring both warmth and authority to his characters made him a respected figure in the television industry throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

About the Character: Christopher Lloyd portrayed Commander Kruge, the Klingon antagonist in Star Trek III: The Search for Spock. Kruge is a ruthless and ambitious Klingon commander who seeks to acquire the secrets of the Genesis Device for use as a weapon. Lloyd’s portrayal of Kruge is fierce and unrelenting, with the character determined to capture the Enterprise and willing to kill Kirk’s son, David, to achieve his goals. Kruge’s death in hand-to-hand combat with Kirk marks the climax of the film, with Lloyd delivering a memorable performance as one of the franchise’s most iconic Klingon villains.
About the Guest:
Christopher Lloyd is an American actor best known for his iconic role as Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown in the Back to the Future trilogy (1985-1990). Lloyd’s portrayal of the eccentric, time-traveling scientist became one of the most beloved characters in film history, with his wild-eyed energy and comedic timing leaving an indelible mark on pop culture. Lloyd’s performance as Doc Brown earned him critical acclaim, and his chemistry with co-star Michael J. Fox helped make Back to the Future one of the most enduring film franchises of all time.

In addition to Back to the Future, Lloyd has had a long and successful career in both film and television. He played the Klingon commander Kruge in Star Trek III: The Search for Spock (1984), a role that showcased his ability to play intense, villainous characters. Lloyd also won two Primetime Emmy Awards for his role as Reverend Jim Ignatowski on the television show Taxi (1978-1983). His versatility and distinctive presence have made him a beloved actor in both comedic and dramatic roles.

About the Character: Ricardo Montalbán played the infamous Khan Noonien Singh in both Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Space Seed" and the film Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan. Khan is a genetically engineered superhuman from the 20th century, exiled by Captain Kirk to a remote planet. In the film, Khan returns with a burning desire for revenge against Kirk, blaming him for the loss of his wife and the hardships endured on the barren planet. Montalbán’s portrayal of Khan is commanding, charismatic, and driven by an intense thirst for vengeance, making him one of Star Trek’s greatest and most memorable villains.
About the Guest:
Ricardo Montalbán was a Mexican actor known for his suave charm and dignified presence, both on screen and off. He achieved international fame for his portrayal of the charismatic yet vengeful Khan Noonien Singh in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Space Seed" and later reprised the role in the critically acclaimed film Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982). Montalbán’s performance as Khan, particularly in the film, is regarded as one of the greatest villains in science fiction, combining both menace and a tragic sense of loss. His portrayal remains one of the high points of the Star Trek franchise.

Beyond Star Trek, Montalbán was best known for his role as Mr. Roarke on the television series Fantasy Island (1977-1984), where he welcomed guests to a mysterious island where their fantasies could come true. Throughout his career, Montalbán worked to combat stereotyping of Latino actors in Hollywood and was a founding member of the Nosotros Foundation, which advocated for greater opportunities for Hispanic actors. His legacy as a trailblazer in the industry and his memorable performances have made him an enduring figure in both television and film.

About the Character: John Colicos portrayed Kor, the first Klingon seen in Star Trek, in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Errand of Mercy." Kor is a ruthless Klingon commander who attempts to conquer the peaceful planet of Organia, only to be thwarted by the godlike Organians. Colicos reprised the role of Kor in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, where Kor appears as an aging but still formidable Klingon warrior. Colicos’ portrayal of Kor set the standard for Klingon characters in Star Trek, combining militaristic aggression with moments of nobility and honor.
About the Guest:
John Colicos was a Canadian actor best known for his roles in science fiction and historical dramas. He made history as the first actor to portray a Klingon on Star Trek: The Original Series, playing the cunning and ruthless Commander Kor in the episode "Errand of Mercy" (1967). Colicos reprised the role of Kor in several episodes of Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, where his character evolved from a scheming antagonist to a more honorable warrior. His portrayal of Kor set the standard for Klingon characters, blending intelligence, humor, and aggression.

In addition to his work on Star Trek, Colicos was well-known for his role as Count Baltar in the original Battlestar Galactica series (1978-1979). His ability to play villains with depth and complexity made him a favorite in the world of science fiction. Colicos had a long career in theater as well, performing in Shakespearean productions and classic dramas. His versatility as an actor, combined with his strong screen presence, made him a beloved figure in genre entertainment and beyond.

About the Character: Ron Perlman played the Reman Viceroy, Shinzon’s second-in-command, in Star Trek: Nemesis. The Viceroy is a Reman, a member of a subjugated race that serves the Romulans. As a loyal enforcer to Shinzon, he plays a key role in the Reman uprising and the plot to destroy Earth. Perlman’s portrayal is menacing, and his character’s physical appearance is heavily enhanced by makeup and prosthetics to create the monstrous visage of the Reman. The Viceroy’s brutal strength and loyalty to Shinzon make him a formidable antagonist in the film.
About the Guest:
Ron Perlman is an American actor known for his distinctive deep voice and strong physical presence, which have allowed him to excel in both live-action and voice acting roles. Perlman first gained widespread recognition for his portrayal of Vincent in the television series Beauty and the Beast (1987-1990), a role that earned him a Golden Globe Award. His performance as the noble, yet tortured, beast showcased his ability to bring depth and emotion to characters hidden beneath heavy prosthetics. Perlman’s career continued to thrive in genre films, where his versatility made him a favorite for roles in fantasy and science fiction.

Perlman is perhaps best known for his portrayal of the titular character in Guillermo del Toro’s Hellboy (2004) and its sequel Hellboy II: The Golden Army (2008). His portrayal of the cigar-chomping, demon-turned-hero Hellboy earned him critical acclaim and a dedicated fanbase. In addition to his work in live-action films, Perlman has enjoyed a prolific career as a voice actor, lending his distinctive voice to animated series and video games such as Fallout, Teen Titans, and Tangled. His long-standing collaborations with directors like Guillermo del Toro have further cemented his legacy as one of Hollywood’s most beloved and respected character actors.

About the Character: Teri Garr portrayed Roberta Lincoln in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "Assignment: Earth." Roberta is an unsuspecting secretary who gets caught up in Gary Seven’s mission to save Earth from nuclear disaster. Initially skeptical and confused by the events, Roberta eventually becomes Gary Seven’s ally, helping him prevent a missile launch that could trigger a global conflict. Garr’s portrayal of Roberta is lighthearted, quirky, and resourceful, offering a comedic counterpoint to the serious stakes of the episode. Her character was intended to continue in a spin-off series, but the idea never materialized.
About the Guest:
Teri Garr is an American actress and comedian best known for her roles in classic films of the 1970s and 1980s. Garr’s breakout role came in Young Frankenstein (1974), where she played the bubbly, eccentric Inga in Mel Brooks’ comedy masterpiece. Her impeccable comedic timing and endearing charm helped make her a favorite in Hollywood, leading to roles in other hit films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Tootsie (1982), and Mr. Mom (1983). In Tootsie, Garr’s portrayal of Sandy, a struggling actress who unknowingly competes with her best friend for a role, earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress.

In addition to her film work, Garr made numerous appearances on television shows such as Friends and The Sonny and Cher Comedy Hour. She was known for her sharp wit and ability to transition between comedy and drama with ease. In her later years, Garr became an advocate for multiple sclerosis (MS) awareness after being diagnosed with the disease in 1999. Her openness about her health challenges and her efforts to raise awareness have added another layer to her legacy as a beloved and inspiring figure in Hollywood.

About the Character: David Soul appeared as Makora, a member of a primitive tribe, in Star Trek: The Original Series episode "The Apple." Makora’s people live under the control of a god-like machine named Vaal, which prevents them from aging or evolving. When Captain Kirk and his crew intervene, Makora begins to question the way of life his people have known for generations. Soul’s portrayal of Makora highlights the character’s innocence and curiosity, as he slowly realizes the implications of freedom from Vaal’s control.
About the Guest:
David Soul is an American-British actor and singer best known for his role as Detective Ken "Hutch" Hutchinson on the hit television series Starsky & Hutch (1975-1979). Soul’s portrayal of the laid-back yet dedicated detective made him a household name during the 1970s, and his on-screen chemistry with co-star Paul Michael Glaser was a key factor in the show’s success. Starsky & Hutch became a cultural phenomenon, and Soul’s portrayal of Hutch remains one of his most iconic roles. His rugged charm and cool demeanor helped define the buddy-cop genre, and the show left a lasting impact on popular culture.

In addition to his acting career, Soul found success as a singer, releasing several albums and achieving a number-one hit with his song "Don't Give Up on Us" in 1977. After Starsky & Hutch, Soul continued to act in television and film, though his career took a quieter turn. He also became a naturalized British citizen and has performed in various stage productions in the UK. Despite stepping away from the limelight in later years, Soul’s impact on both television and music during his heyday remains significant, with Starsky & Hutch continuing to enjoy cult status.

About the Character: Kurtwood Smith played Annorax, the obsessed temporal scientist, in Star Trek: Voyager two-part episode "Year of Hell." Annorax commands a Krenim temporal weapon ship that can erase entire civilizations from history in his quest to restore his timeline and bring back his wife. Smith’s portrayal of Annorax is a tragic and nuanced one, as his character is consumed by guilt and driven by a single-minded desire to undo the past. His performance adds emotional depth to a story about the dangers of time manipulation and the personal toll it takes on those who wield it.
About the Guest:
Kurtwood Smith is an American actor best known for his roles as authoritarian and often villainous characters. He gained widespread recognition for his portrayal of Clarence Boddicker, the sadistic crime boss, in RoboCop (1987). Smith’s cold, calculating performance as Boddicker made him one of the most memorable villains in 1980s cinema, and his ability to portray menacing, morally corrupt characters became a hallmark of his career. Smith’s versatility as an actor, however, extends beyond villain roles, as he has taken on a variety of characters across genres, from science fiction to drama.

Smith is also well-known for his role as Red Forman, the strict, no-nonsense father, on the hit sitcom That '70s Show (1998-2006). His performance as Red, complete with his iconic catchphrase "dumbass," became a central part of the show’s humor, and his gruff but ultimately loving character resonated with audiences. Outside of his work on That '70s Show, Smith has appeared in numerous films and television series, including Dead Poets Society (1989), 24, and Star Trek: Voyager, where he played the complex time-traveling villain Annorax. His ability to seamlessly transition between comedy and drama has made him a respected and enduring figure in Hollywood.

About the Character: Saul Rubinek portrayed Kivas Fajo, a wealthy and amoral collector, in Star Trek: The Next Generation episode "The Most Toys." Fajo kidnaps Data and attempts to add him to his collection of unique and irreplaceable items. Rubinek’s portrayal of Fajo is both charming and sinister, as he takes pleasure in the control he exerts over others, particularly Data, whose ethical programming is tested during captivity. The character’s ruthless behavior and the tension he creates with Data make this one of the more psychologically intense episodes of the series. Rubinek's nuanced performance adds depth to the villainy of Kivas Fajo, making him a memorable antagonist.
About the Guest:
Saul Rubinek is a Canadian actor and director known for his work across film, television, and theater. He gained recognition for his roles in Unforgiven (1992), where he played the journalist W.W. Beauchamp, and in True Romance (1993), where he portrayed a pompous Hollywood producer. Rubinek’s ability to blend humor with dramatic intensity has made him a versatile actor, capable of playing both comedic and serious roles with equal skill. His filmography includes a wide range of genres, from action and Westerns to dramas and comedies, showcasing his adaptability as a performer.

In addition to his film work, Rubinek is well known for his role as Kivas Fajo in Star Trek: The Next Generation, where he played a villainous collector who kidnaps Data. He also starred as Artie Nielsen in the Syfy series Warehouse 13 (2009-2014), where he brought a mix of eccentricity and warmth to the character of a government agent tasked with protecting supernatural artifacts. Rubinek’s work as a director and producer further demonstrates his commitment to the craft of storytelling, and his long and varied career has earned him a respected place in both Canadian and American entertainment.
